content.raw:
Thanks for the explanation. It sounds reasonable, however there is a benefit to sticking to our style standards for code that we create and distribute. One benefit is consistency across libraries.  Another benefit is that a switch in style is a signal to a user that they are now leaving ignition/gazebo/etc and entering a different library. I'd also prefer not to create a list of exceptions to the already long list of rules. 

The return type of the function should be enough information to a user that they will get a `std::shared_ptr`.
content.html:
Thanks for the explanation. It sounds reasonable, however there is a benefit to sticking to our style standards for code that we create and distribute. One benefit is consistency across libraries. Another benefit is that a switch in style is a signal to a user that they are now leaving ignition/gazebo/etc and entering a different library. I'd also prefer not to create a list of exceptions to the already long list of rules.

The return type of the function should be enough information to a user that they will get a std::shared_ptr.

content.html:
I believe doxygen will treat each function independently when the function has some doxygen style comments. You can refer back to a specific function by reference that function's exact signature. For example, you could add a see also here:

\sa Interface *GetInterface(const std::string &_interfaceName);

pull_request.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

update.description:
This is a reduced version of the Plugin Framework Pull Request #59.

This PR does not have the template specializations (which are needed for good performance) nor the `PluginPtr` class (which is needed for the template specializations). Since those were perhaps the most complex parts of the implementation, their removal might help the review process a little bit since reviewers can now focus their attention somewhat.

Ultimately, I expect the template specializations and `PluginPtr` to be merged in as well (unless we can come up with a nicer implementation that provides the same performance, but I don't currently believe that's possible, not that I would discourage anyone from trying).

Note that there are some vestigial functions in this pull request which aren't strictly needed in the absence of the template specialization, so that may cause some confusion during the review, but I'd prefer not to pollute the version history with too many redundant removals and insertions, so I'm going to leave them in unless reviewers would strongly prefer that they be taken out.

As a quick overview of what this PR specifically offers:

1. The plugin framework can now support arbitrarily many plugins per library, and arbitrarily many interface per plugin.

2. The `PluginLoader` class now returns a generic `PluginPtr` (in this PR the `PluginPtr` is a `std::shared_ptr<Plugin>`, but that will change in pull request #59). The generic `Plugin` object grants access to the interfaces provided by the plugin that was loaded.

3. Interfaces can be retrieved as `std::shared_ptr<T>` objects where `T` is one of the interfaces provided by the loaded plugin. This allows a user to simply query the `Plugin` for the specific interfaces that they want, and then discard the generic `PluginPtr` that was originally returned by the `PluginLoader`.
update.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
I had two motivations for having `Private` in the name:

1. Avoid name collisions (or more accurately, name confusion) between this function and the public-facing `GetInterface<T>(~)` function
2. Emphasize that this is not a function that should be considered for use by an end-user.

Technically there would not be a name collision between this function and `GetInterface<T>(~)` even if we removed the `Private` because one function is templated and the other isn't. However, I'd like to avoid issue tickets where users are asking why they can't retrieve an interface using `plugin->GetInterface(myInterfaceName)` when the only problem is that they forgot to specify the template parameter.
content.html:
I had two motivations for having Private in the name:

  1. Avoid name collisions (or more accurately, name confusion) between this function and the public-facing GetInterface<T>(~) function
  2. Emphasize that this is not a function that should be considered for use by an end-user.

Technically there would not be a name collision between this function and GetInterface<T>(~) even if we removed the Private because one function is templated and the other isn't. However, I'd like to avoid issue tickets where users are asking why they can't retrieve an interface using plugin->GetInterface(myInterfaceName) when the only problem is that they forgot to specify the template parameter.

pull_request.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw: Since the documentation of this function is simply referring to the documentation of another function (which I think improves maintainability in cases like this), I think we should keep the text here as minimal as possible. I believe doxygen should automatically turn the text `GetInterface<Interface>(std::string)` into a link, although it seems we don't currently have the ignition projects configured to generate doxygen output (or at least, `make doc` on this branch is just producing a bunch of skeleton html pages with none of the actual documentation in it).
content.html: Since the documentation of this function is simply referring to the documentation of another function (which I think improves maintainability in cases like this), I think we should keep the text here as minimal as possible. I believe doxygen should automatically turn the text GetInterface<Interface>(std::string) into a link, although it seems we don't currently have the ignition projects configured to generate doxygen output (or at least, make doc on this branch is just producing a bunch of skeleton html pages with none of the actual documentation in it).

content.raw: Similar to `InterfaceMap`, it's labeled `public` for technical C++ syntax reasons, but it's not something that end-users should have to see or be aware of, so I don't think it belongs in the "Public API" section. They shouldn't really be inheriting the `Plugin` class, even if the destructor is virtual.
content.html: Similar to InterfaceMap, it's labeled public for technical C++ syntax reasons, but it's not something that end-users should have to see or be aware of, so I don't think it belongs in the "Public API" section. They shouldn't really be inheriting the Plugin class, even if the destructor is virtual.

pull_request.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw: I grouped it with the private API because it's not something which should be utilized by end-users, but we need it to be labeled `public` because there are other internal classes which benefit from having this `using` declaration be public.
content.html: I grouped it with the private API because it's not something which should be utilized by end-users, but we need it to be labeled public because there are other internal classes which benefit from having this using declaration be public.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
In the original pull request, there was an explanation of why I named it like this, but it seems to have gotten lost in the decomposition. The gist of it is:

The role of this function is to covert from our custom `PluginPtr` class (which was left out of this pull request, but is being introduced in pull request 59) to an STL-based `std::shared_ptr` class, so the change in code style is meant to reflect that transition. After all, we're giving them a `shared_ptr`, not a `SharedPtr`.
content.html:
In the original pull request, there was an explanation of why I named it like this, but it seems to have gotten lost in the decomposition. The gist of it is:

The role of this function is to covert from our custom PluginPtr class (which was left out of this pull request, but is being introduced in pull request 59) to an STL-based std::shared_ptr class, so the change in code style is meant to reflect that transition. After all, we're giving them a shared_ptr, not a SharedPtr.

content.raw:
I'm genuinely not sure how to approach doxygen (or doxygen-like) documentation for macros, since `///` cannot be used for comments in macros due to the "single-line" nature of a macro.

I can put comments inside of `/* .... */` blocks, but I don't think it will be registered by doxygen. If that's good enough, then I'll go ahead and do that.
content.html:
I'm genuinely not sure how to approach doxygen (or doxygen-like) documentation for macros, since /// cannot be used for comments in macros due to the "single-line" nature of a macro.

I can put comments inside of /* .... */ blocks, but I don't think it will be registered by doxygen. If that's good enough, then I'll go ahead and do that.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw:
Whether `-1` is singular or plural is a loaded question, which I think depends a lot on context. You can find a whole discussion on it [here](https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/9735/is-1-followed-by-a-singular-or-plural-noun).

I think the view I favor the most is [this one](https://english.stackexchange.com/a/9743), but it's not terribly helpful since the conclusion is that sometimes it will be singular and sometimes it will be plural, depending on how the quantity is being read.

I have no problem restricting the singular case to *only* be when `_n==1` if that's what people would prefer.
content.html:
Whether -1 is singular or plural is a loaded question, which I think depends a lot on context. You can find a whole discussion on it here.

I think the view I favor the most is this one, but it's not terribly helpful since the conclusion is that sometimes it will be singular and sometimes it will be plural, depending on how the quantity is being read.

I have no problem restricting the singular case to only be when _n==1 if that's what people would prefer.

pullrequest.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

content.raw: This is used for the case that we want to "empty" a plugin, emulating the behavior of a `nullptr` reference (maybe we're resetting the plugin, or we're letting go of the plugin instance so that we can safely unload its library). It's a valid operation to perform, and we wouldn't expect the caller to handle it any differently whether or not `_info` is a `nullptr`.
content.html: This is used for the case that we want to "empty" a plugin, emulating the behavior of a nullptr reference (maybe we're resetting the plugin, or we're letting go of the plugin instance so that we can safely unload its library). It's a valid operation to perform, and we wouldn't expect the caller to handle it any differently whether or not _info is a nullptr.

content.raw: If this line of code is ever executed, then there is a serious bug which needs to be fixed. Returning a boolean for success would imply that we expect the caller of the function to handle a case in which it fails, but that's something that should never occur if the code is working as intended, so we shouldn't prompt them to expect it.
content.html: If this line of code is ever executed, then there is a serious bug which needs to be fixed. Returning a boolean for success would imply that we expect the caller of the function to handle a case in which it fails, but that's something that should never occur if the code is working as intended, so we shouldn't prompt them to expect it.

content.raw: `const` variables automatically have "internal linkage" which (in this context) would be the same as the effect caused by declaring them `static`, so it would be redundant.
content.html: const variables automatically have "internal linkage" which (in this context) would be the same as the effect caused by declaring them static, so it would be redundant.

content.raw: Right now, this just emits a warning and then continues as normal. Since we're not supporting multiple versions yet, I can't predict what logic we should use for handling multiple versions, since it will depend on how we go about implementing backwards compatibility. This version check is just a gentle indication to the user that a newer version is available. If we don't want to provide the user with that warning (maybe it would be spammy if they're loading many plugin libraries?), then I'm definitely open to removing it.
content.html: Right now, this just emits a warning and then continues as normal. Since we're not supporting multiple versions yet, I can't predict what logic we should use for handling multiple versions, since it will depend on how we go about implementing backwards compatibility. This version check is just a gentle indication to the user that a newer version is available. If we don't want to provide the user with that warning (maybe it would be spammy if they're loading many plugin libraries?), then I'm definitely open to removing it.

content.raw:
`Info` in this case is a function name, which is why it's capitalized.

The `auto` keyword makes it non-obvious that `Info` is a function, but the alternative syntax is genuinely atrocious:

    std::size_t(*Info)(void * const, std::size_t, std::size_t) =
        reinterpret_cast<PluginLoadFunctionSignature>(multiInfoPtr);

How about I put in a comment to explain what `Info` is and what it's doing?
content.html:
Info in this case is a function name, which is why it's capitalized.

The auto keyword makes it non-obvious that Info is a function, but the alternative syntax is genuinely atrocious:

std::size_t(*Info)(void * const, std::size_t, std::size_t) =
    reinterpret_cast<PluginLoadFunctionSignature>(multiInfoPtr);

How about I put in a comment to explain what Info is and what it's doing?
